title: 110_hr1000
content: The Act is titled the "Edward William Brooke III Congressional Gold Medal Act". Senator Edward William Brooke III was the first African American elected to the US Senate by popular vote, serving two terms from 1967 to 1979. Before his Senate career, he made significant contributions as the Attorney General of Massachusetts, pioneering legislation for consumer protection and fighting against discrimination and pollution. Senator Edward William Brooke III was elected as the first African American Attorney General of Massachusetts, known for his fearless prosecution of organized crime and honest execution of state laws. Raised in Washington, DC during a time of segregation, he achieved pioneering accomplishments in public service. Senator Brooke, a native Washingtonian, graduated from Paul Laurence Dunbar High School and Howard University. He served in the segregated 366th Infantry Regiment during World War II, achieving the rank of captain and receiving a Bronze Star Medal and Distinguished Service Award. His advocacy for self-government and voting rights for DC residents stems from his personal experiences. Senator Brooke attended Boston University School of Law, graduating with an LL.B. in 1948 and an LL.M. in 1949. He was a leader on critical issues during his career in Congress, including the war in Vietnam, civil rights, apartheid in South Africa, the Cold War, and US relations with China. President Lyndon B. Johnson appointed him to the President's Commission on Civil Disorders in 1967, where his work on discrimination in housing influenced the 1968 Civil Rights Act. Senator Brooke was a champion of open housing and received numerous high honors, including the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2004 and the NAACP Spingarn Medal. He was the first African American to have a State courthouse named in his honor. Senator Brooke, a racial pioneer, demonstrated that barriers can be overcome with commitment and determination. He devoted his life to serving others and made significant contributions to society. His life and accomplishments serve as inspiring proof that people can be elected based on qualifications, not race. Congress authorizes the presentation of a gold medal to Edward William Brooke III for his exceptional service to the nation. The medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, provisions for duplicate medals are included. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price covering all costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Proceeds from sales can be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the costs of medals struck under this Act. Amounts from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited back into the Fund.
